Eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a real matrix

    Dark Mode
  • Index

        getImagEigenvalues
      • getImagEigenvalues[T](ei: EigenvalueDecomposition[T]): lent seq[T]
  Source   Edit

If A is symmetric, then A = V*D*V' where the eigenvalue matrix D is diagonal and the eigenvector matrix V is orthogonal. I.e. A = V*D*V.transpose() and V*V.transpose() equals the identity matrix.

If A is not symmetric, then the eigenvalue matrix D is block diagonal with the real eigenvalues in 1-by-1 blocks and any complex eigenvalues, lambda + i * mu, in 2-by-2 blocks, [lambda, mu; -mu, lambda]. The columns of V represent the eigenvectors in the sense that A*V = V*D, i.e. A*V equals V*D. The matrix V may be badly conditioned, or even singular, so the validity of the equation A = V*D*inverse(V) depends upon V.cond().

Imports

matrix

Check for symmetry, then construct the eigenvalue decomposition.

  • return: Structure to access D and V.
